revised_title: Evolutionary Hypothesis of Vision and Color Perception
tldr: The author proposes an evolutionary hypothesis for vision and color perception, suggesting that the eye's ability to distinguish colors developed in relation to environmental pigments. The hypothesis explains why the outer parts of the retina are colorblind and why minimal stimuli from colored objects appear as shades of gray. The author also explores how the combination of red and green spectral rays produces the sensation of yellow and how certain pairs of spectral rays create gray or white sensations.
